key_risks: Regulatory and compliance risks due to operating in highly regulated markets
Climate and environmental risks, including natural disasters and rising claims costs
Competitive pressures from digital-first insurers and traditional competitors
Operational and financial risks, including dependence on technology providers and IT infrastructure
controversies: Scrutiny over governance issues and executive compensation
Reputational risks related to environmental policies and divestment from unconventional oil and gas sectors
environmental_issues: Exposure to climate-related risks and natural disasters
Commitment to reducing exposure to unconventional oil and gas sectors
social_issues: Ethical concerns related to environmental policies and governance
governance_issues: Governance issues and executive compensation scrutiny

sources.title: Assicurazioni Generali - Wikipedia
sources.snippet: Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. (/ ˌ dʒ ɛ n ə ˈ r ɑː l i / JEN-ər-AH-lee, Italian: [assikuratˈtsjoːni dʒeneˈraːli]; meaning 'general insurances') or commonly known as Generali Group is an Italian insurance company based in Trieste. [2] As of 2022, it is the largest insurance company in Italy and ranks among the world's largest insurance companies by net premiums and assets.

sources.title: Investor Relations - Generali Group
sources.snippet: Generali is one of the largest global insurance and asset management providers. Established in 1831, it is present in over 50 countries in the world, with a total premium income of € 82.5 billion in 2023. With almost 82,000 employees serving 70 million customers, the Group has a leading position in Europe and a growing presence in Asia and Latin America.
